<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// SystemZ wants normal register scavenging slots, as close to the stack or</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// frame pointer as possible.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The default implementation assumes an x86-like layout, where the frame</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// pointer is at the opposite end of the frame from the stack pointer.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This meant that when frame pointer elimination was disabled,</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the slots ended up being as close as possible to the incoming</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// stack pointer, which is the opposite of what we want on SystemZ.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordflow">return</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">false</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><Highlight kind="normal">  &#125;</Highlight></CodeLine>
